Award.AwardTitle: Understanding the Deformation of Heterogeneous Nanocrystalline Metals - Integrating in situ Experiments with Stochastic Crystal Plasticity

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nanocrystalline metals are materials composed of grains (crystallites) whose sizes are of the order of 100 nanometers or less. The small grain size endows these materials with several desirable properties including very high strength and increased toughness compared to conventional metals. However, many commonly used methods to produce nanocrystalline metals lead to highly nonuniform microstructures with a wide distribution in the size and orientation of grains. Such heterogeneous microstructures lead to a large variability in their mechanical properties, which limits their practical use. This award supports fundamental research to predict and quantify uncertainty in the mechanical properties of heterogeneous nanocrystalline metals using a combined experimental and modeling approach. The ability to reliably and accurately predict the behavior of nanocrystalline metals would hasten their adoption in technological and scientific structural applications, which will directly benefit the U.S. economy and society. This research involves a multi-disciplinary approach comprising of advanced microfabrication, materials science and mechanics and will lead to broader engagement of underrepresented groups in research and positively impact engineering education.

Nanocrystalline metals with a wide or bimodal grain size distribution often exhibit the best combination of strength and ductility and hence are very attractive from an engineering perspective. However, to accurately predict the mechanical response of these materials it is necessary to consider both their intrinsic microstructural heterogeneity and the stochastic nature of nanoscale plasticity. Motivated by this, a new stochastic crystal plasticity framework informed by in situ experiments will be used to model the deformation of heterogeneous nanocrystalline metals. The model will explicitly take into account both the variation in grain sizes and orientations as well as the statistics of dislocation bursts in nanocrystalline metals. Novel in situ transmission electron microscopy experiments on nanocrystalline metal films with controlled microstructures will be used to directly obtain input parameters for the model such as the distribution of critical resolved shear stresses. The predictive capability of the model will be verified with data from independent in situ x-ray diffraction experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of the project was to improve our understanding of the deformation behavior of metals composed of very fine crystallites/grains (nano or ultrafine grains). A combined experimental and modeling approach was adopted for this purpose. The experiments and the developed models have provided several key insights on the deformation behavior of nanocrystalline/ultrafine-grained (NC/UFG) metals.

 

Experiments have shown that

1. The mechanical behavior of NC/UFG aluminum films with random orientations of grains is very sensitive to the rate at which the deformation is applied. In technical terminology, randomly oriented NC/UFG aluminum films are highly strain rate sensitive. This result is unexpected because aluminum is considered to be a rate insensitive material.

2. The mechanical behavior of NC/UFG aluminum films with a strong texture (grains have same orientation in one or more directions) is far less sensitive to the applied deformation rate.

3. In textured UFG aluminum films, the direction of loading has a notable impact on the measured properties like strength and strain hardening.

4. In UFG aluminum films with a random texture, significant microstructural evolution (changes in grain size, shape, etc.) occurs during deformation via twinning/detwinning. This is highly unusual since twinning is not a common mode of deformation in aluminum.

 

Modeling efforts have led to

1. Development of a crystal plasticity framework that is capable of quantitatively simulating the mechanical behavior of UFG metal films with both a bicrystalline (only two families of grains) and random microstructure.

2. Identification of grain boundary deformation as a significant source of compliance in UFG aluminum films and helped explain the high strain rate sensitivity in the randomly oriented aluminum films.

 

The project has had a substantial impact in terms of human capital development by

1. Supporting two PhD students who worked on the experimental aspects of the project. The two students developed skills related to thin film deposition and characterization, microfabrication, in situ testing and analysis of crystal orientation data. Both students are now employed in research and development positions in semiconductor industry.

2. Supporting three students who worked on the modeling aspects of the project. The three students have developed skills related to 3-D microstructure reconstruction based on crystallographic data obtained experimentally, finite element modeling of anisotropic materials and crystal plasticity simulations. One of these students is currently an Assistant Professor in a public university. 

 

The project has also enabled significant outreach activities, including demonstration of microscale materials testing to about 400 high school students as part of the Summer Engineering Experience program at Arizona State University.


Last Modified: 11/12/2018
Modified by: Jagannathan Rajagopalan

The experiments and the developed models have provided several key insights on the deformation behavior of nanocrystalline/ultrafine-grained (NC/UFG) metals. Experiments have shown that 1. In textured UFG aluminum films, the direction of loading has a notable impact on the measured properties like strength and strain hardening. 4. In UFG aluminum films with a random texture, significant microstructural evolution (changes in grain size, shape, etc.) occurs during deformation via twinning/detwinning. This is highly unusual since twinning is not a common mode of deformation in aluminum. Modeling efforts have led to 1.
